1. Eczema of lower leg

Cellulitis
Chronic kidney disease
LVAD (left ventricular assist device) present
Skin problem
Patient with end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis, CHF s/p LVAD, medical noncompliance
Admitted with recurrent painful area on the right leg which has been treated previously with antibiotics without any improvement
He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics for at least a month without any improvement
Topical steroids and mupirocin started by dermatology,
Skin biopsy culture is growing Enterobacter, will continue cefepime for now
Follow path, still pending
No objection to discharge home on oral minocycline 100 mg twice daily for 10 days
Patient is to follow with dermatology to review pathology results and clinical follow-up
Discussed with him
Tariq Mehmood, MD FIDSA

Cont HD MWF at DaVita W Broadway starting 6/25, Arrive at 6.20 am with VAD Caregiver. Bring VAD binder with you. HD session starts at 0700 hrs.

wound care: Clean right leg lesions with normal saline, apply Mupirocin Ointment and Triamcinolone cream daily, wrap with Kerlix and ACE bandage.

Code Status
Start: 2022-02-16 19:31:00 EDT, Full Code, Continuous Order

Mr Parker is a 51 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), s/p HM3 as DT on 2021-10-24, CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA, CKD stage 4, HD MWF with ongoing RLE cellulitis and pain. Pt admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis/pain, afebrile, WBC WNL, Procal WNL.

Upon admission, empiric ABx started, consulted ID, derm and vascular. s/p punch biopsy of the crusted plaque RLE per derm pending path report. Cultures showed Klebsiella+, received Cefepime per ID while inpatient. He is to continue Minocycline 100 mg po BID for 10 days per ID recs. Redness, pain and drainage improved with saline compresses, Mupirocin Oint and Triamcinolone cream B I D, with compression Ace bandages toes to knee B I D after soaks and topical medications applied. Derm recs to continue daily Mupirocin Ointment and Triamcinolone cream daily, wrap with Kerlix and ACE bandage and follow up with Derm in 2 weeks. Norco for pain control currently, provided Norco 10 tid for 2 days. he is to see UofL pain management for further recommendations on managing pain at home.
From HF standpoint, BP/ Volume/Vad stable. BP /MAP was found above goal while inpatient, coreg increased to 25 mg po bid, tolerating. Followed by nephrology while inpatient, continued HD MWF with last session today. He is to continue HD on MWF, next session on 2022-02-25.
Discharge plan has been discussed with patient, and he agrees to discharge at this time. Discharge instructions have been provided and patient verbalized his understanding. Discharge plan has been discussed with attending Dr. Moore and patient is stable for discharge home at this time.
During the course of his stay, the following issues were addressed:
# RLE cellulitis/infected eczema of right leg
afebrile, WBC WNL, Procal WNL
-worsening redness, rash, and swelling with small open areas and scabs on admission now improved
-recently completed 5 days IV Vanc and Zosyn then oral Augmentin 500 mg daily for 5 days
-Derm following
-s/p punch biopsy of the crusted plaque RLE per derm pending path report.
-Cultures show Klebsiella+, Cefepime per ID.
--Minocycline 100 mg po BID for 10 days per ID recs.
- Derm recs to continue daily Mupirocin Ointment and Triamcinolone cream daily, wrap with Kerlix and ACE bandage
-follow up with Derm in 2 weeks.
- Norco for pain control currently, provided Norco 10 tid for 2 days. he is to see UofL pain management for further recommendations on managing pain at home.
# Chronic HFrEF
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24

Discussed with Dr. Dwivedi. Suspect if any vascular issue, may be more related to venous insufficiency. Can tentatively plan for CO2 angiogram on Friday to assess arterial vasculature.

# RLE cellulitis
afebrile, WBC WNL, Procal WNL
-worsening redness, rash, and swelling with small open areas and scabs on admission now improved
-recently completed 5 days IV Vanc and Zosyn then oral Augmentin 500 mg daily for 5 days
-Derm following
-s/p punch biopsy of the crusted plaque RLE per derm pending path report.
-Cultures show Klebsiella+, on Cefepime per ID.
- Derm recs normal saline compresses Mupirocin Oint and Triamcinolone cream B I D, compression Ace bandages toes to knee B I D after soaks and topical medications applied.
-Norco for pain control currently.
# Chronic HFrEF
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
LVAD interrogated: stable
Speed/LSL: 6000/5600
Flow: 5.3
Power: 4.9
PI: 3.9
PI events: none
Alarms: none in last 24 hours
Changes made: None
DLES Stage: 2
LDH: 136
HF/ VAD education provided
Volume: near optivolemic
Diuretics: Bumex 4 mg po BID, HD MWF
BB: Coreg 18.75 mg po bid
Hydralazine 150 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
AC: ASA, Eliquis
DLES: dressing changes daily with Medihoney.
# CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
# Persistent Afib
- Amio PO 200 mg daily
- AC as above
#CKD, stage IV
--Cr baseline 2-2.5
--s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10
--s/p insertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 2022-01-14 with Vascular.
--HD M W fr
- nephrology following
# Uncontrolled DM type 2
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04 and 5.6 on 3/30
- Recently reduced Lantus to 20 units daily and lispro 3 units AC tid + SSi d/t hypoglycemia, will continue
# Hx Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Hx substance abuse
-hx smoking marijuana for several years, now states quit since VAD implant
-2022-02-03 UDS + for opiates and tricyclic antidepressant, no opiates were prescribed for pt
-Reports excruciating pain RLE for which he has taken some Lortab 10 mg that he bought from his friend.
- started on Norco for short period of time for pain and cellulitis of RLE
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.
A/P:
Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis/pain, afebrile, WBC WNL, Procal WNL. s/p punch biopsy of the crusted plaque RLE per derm pending path report. Cultures show Klebsiella+, on Cefepime per ID. Derm recs normal saline compresses Mupirocin Oint and Triamcinolone cream B I D, compression Ace bandages toes to knee B I D after soaks and topical medications applied. Norco for pain control currently.
From HF standpoint, BP/ Volume/Vad stable. Will continue HD on MWF, appreciate nephrology assistance.

Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis/pain, afebrile, WBC WNL, Procal WNL. Pt recently completed 5 days IV Vanc and Zosyn then oral Augmentin 500 mg daily for 5 days. 6/19 - no change skin BX pending
From HF standpoint, BP/ Volume/Vad stable. Will continue HD on MWF, appreciate nephrology assistance.

Patient with end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis, CHF s/p LVAD, medical noncompliance
Admitted with recurrent painful area on the right leg which has been treated previously with antibiotics without any improvement

Right leg pain, currently being tx for cellulitis in said leg, pain worsening, VAD patient

This is a 51-year-old white male with a history of congestive heart failure status post LVAD placement, end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis and medical noncompliance.
He has been admitted several times with painful right leg with mild erythema and has been treated repeatedly with courses of antibiotics only with transient relief. During his last admission he received several days of IV antibiotics followed by oral antibiotics. All his cultures have been negative.
He is admitted again with similar symptoms of swelling pain and erythema limited to same area. He has no fever chills or leukocytosis.
Patient main symptom is intense pain in that area and he would not allow me to touch it at this time.
He denies any injury, bites or trauma to that area

Cellulitis
Chronic kidney disease
Hypertension

Skin problem
Patient with end-stage kidney disease on hemodialysis, CHF s/p LVAD, medical noncompliance
Admitted with recurrent painful area on the right leg which has been treated previously with antibiotics without any improvement
Physical appearance of this area is not consistent with infection or cellulitis
I think this patient should be seen by dermatologist for possible skin biopsy to rule out possible infiltrative disease like erythema nodosum, sarcoidosis, or other skin diseases
Will not recommend any antibiotic treatment at this time
We will discuss
Tariq Mehmood, MD FIDSA

Patient: PARKER, Michael Daniel mrn:c485842938 fin:v4207557352
Age: 51 Years Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03
Right leg pain, currently being tx for cellulitis in said leg, pain worsening, VAD patient

This is a 51-year-old Caucasian male currently admitted to Jewish Hospital with right leg cellulitis. This is a patient we have seen in the past. On 2022-01-10 Dr. Dwivedi placed a right arm brachiocephalic fistula. He also has a right chest tunneled dialysis catheter he currently uses for dialysis. This is a patient with ischemic cardiomyopathy. He has a HeartMate 3 ventricular assist device. We saw him in consultation during another admission on 2022-02-04. At that time the right leg was causing excruciating pain. He would not let me touch the limb. The swelling and excruciating pain has now somewhat abated and he allowed me to get a better look at it. The right anterior shin has patchy red rash/discoloration. Right foot is warm and dry. No sores or wounds to the foot.

2022-02-16 13:36 EDT Chief Complaint Right leg pain, currently being tx for cellulitis in said leg, pain worsening, VAD patient .

History of Present Illness
The patient presents with rash. 51-year old male with ischemic cardiomyopathy with placement of a HeartMate 3 LVAD in February, history of end-stage renal disease maintained on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday hemodialysis ,and diabetes who presents with cellulitis of his right leg. Patient was apparently admitted earlier this month and was treated with IV antibiotics. He was discharged with Augmentin x5 days on the eighth. He reports he is not currently on antibiotics. He is having persistent right leg pain, swelling, and redness. He states it has been difficult to sleep secondary to his discomfort. His appetite has been poor. He endorses night sweats last evening. Last dialysis session was this morning. The patient denies any shortness of breath. No recent alarms on his LVAD. Denies any discharge or erythema around his driveline site or right-sided tunneled catheter. He does state that he has persistent lower extremity edema. He does still produce urine.

Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation, respirations are non-labored, BS equal bilaterally.
Chest wall: No tenderness, No deformity, Right sided tunneled catheter appears normal. No discharge. No tenderness to palpation.
Musculoskeletal: Normal ROM, Lateral +1 brawny edema. There is a pretibial area of erythema that includes the entire shin. This is tender to palpation. No exudate. This does not extend into the ankle or foot..
Gastrointestinal: Soft, Nontender, Non distended, Right-sided driveline site is nontender to palpation. There is some surrounding erythema which is felt to be secondary to a probable tape allergy..
Neurological: Alert and oriented to person, place, time, and situation, No focal neurological deficit observed.
Psychiatric: Cooperative.

Medical Decision Making
Differential Diagnosis: Skin rash, cellulitis, dermatitis.
Rationale: Discussed with ARNP with heart failure. The patient has a history of substance abuse. Pain control will be a challenge and might be the major contributing factor to his issues today.
Documents reviewed: Patient was last admitted the third through the eighth for cellulitis of the right leg..

text.paragraph: No data available for this section
No data available for this section

Ventricular Assist Device, Adult
A ventricular assist device (VAD) is a mechanical pump that helps the two lower chambers of the heart (ventricles) pump blood. You may need a VAD if you have a medical condition that affects the heart muscle, such as:
• Heart failure.
• A major heart attack (myocardial infarction).
• An infection that weakens the heart muscle.
Why do I need a VAD?
A VAD helps the ventricles pump blood to the body. It may be used:
• To support your heart until ventricle function improves.
• To support your heart until you are able to have a heart transplant.
• To permanently support your heart if you have end-stage heart failure and you are not a candidate for a heart transplant.
How does a VAD work?
A VAD is implanted in your chest and is connected to your heart and blood vessels through tubes. The mechanical pump moves blood through your heart. A VAD has the following parts:
• Inflow tube. This tube carries oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to the VAD pump.
• Outflow tube. This tube carries blood from the VAD pump to the aorta. The aorta is the main blood vessel that delivers oxygenated blood to the body.
• A mechanical pump. This is usually implanted in your chest, but it may be outside of your body depending on which type of VAD you have.
• Swanson controller. The controller consists of batteries and electronics that control the VAD. The Swanson controller sits outside of your body.
• Percutaneous lead. This is the wire that connects the VAD pump to the Swanson controller. The wire is put through a small opening in your abdomen.
Blood may be pumped through the VAD in one of the following ways:
• Pulse flow. Blood is pumped through the VAD at regular intervals, similar to a normal heartbeat.
• Continuous flow. Blood is pumped through the VAD at a steady rate (continuously). This means that you may not feel a pulse.
What are the different types of VADs?
The type of VAD that you need depends on your heart condition and other health conditions that you may have. Your health care provider will determine which type of device you need. Types of VADs include:
• Left ventricular assist device (LVAD). This is the most common type of VAD. It helps the left ventricle pump blood to the aorta.
• Right ventricular assist device (RVAD). This helps pump blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.
• Biventricular assist device (BIVAD). This combines an LVAD and an RVAD. A BIVAD helps the ventricles pump blood to the aorta and the lungs.
• Transcutaneous VAD. This is also called a bedside VAD. This is used in emergency or short-term situations. The pump is located outside of your body.
What are the risks of having a VAD?
Generally, VAD implantation and use is safe. However, problems may occur, including:
• Infection. You may be prescribed antibiotic medicine to help prevent infection.
• Bleeding or blood clots.
◦ You will be prescribed blood thinners (anticoagulants) to prevent blood clots.
◦ You will have frequent blood samples to measure how quickly your blood clots.
• Allergic reactions to medicines.
• Damage to other structures or organs.
◦ This may include right-sided heart failure if you have an LVAD.
• Stroke. A stroke may be caused by:
◦ A blood clot (ischemic stroke).
◦ Bleeding in the brain (hemorrhagic stroke).
• A device that fails to work (VAD malfunction).
What are the benefits of a VAD?
Benefits of having a VAD may include:
• Reduced strain on your heart.
• A better chance that you may receive a heart transplant.
• Being able to do things that you could not do before getting a VAD, such as exercising or traveling.
• The potential recovery of heart muscle function.
How is a VAD implanted?
A VAD is implanted with open heart surgery. After the procedure, you will recover in an intensive care unit (ICU). A machine (ventilator) will help move air in and out of your lungs until you can breathe on your own.
Summary
• A ventricular assist device (VAD) is a mechanical pump that helps the heart pump blood.
• You may need this device to support your heart until the ventricle function improves or until you are able to have a heart transplant.
• A VAD has several parts, including a pump, tubes to carry blood, a Swanson controller, and a lead.
• The type of VAD that you need depends on your heart condition and other health conditions that you may have. Your health care provider will determine which type of device you need.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-07-25 Document Reviewed: 2020-07-25
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Heart Failure, Diagnosis
Heart failure means that your heart is not able to pump blood in the right way. This makes it hard for your body to work well. Heart failure is usually a long-term (chronic) condition. You must take good care of yourself and follow your treatment plan from your doctor.
What are the causes?
This condition may be caused by:
• High blood pressure.
• Build up of cholesterol and fat in the arteries.
• Heart attack. This injures the heart muscle.
• Heart valves that do not open and close properly.
• Damage of the heart muscle. This is also called cardiomyopathy.
• Lung disease.
• Abnormal heart rhythms.
What increases the risk?
The risk of heart failure goes up as a person ages. This condition is also more likely to develop in people who:
• Are overweight.
• Are male.
• Smoke or chew tobacco.
• Abuse alcohol or illegal drugs.
• Have taken medicines that can damage the heart.
• Have diabetes.
• Have abnormal heart rhythms.
• Have thyroid problems.
• Have low blood counts (anemia).
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Shortness of breath.
• Coughing.
• Swelling of the feet, ankles, legs, or belly.
• Losing weight for no reason.
• Trouble breathing.
• Waking from sleep because of the need to sit up and get more air.
• Rapid heartbeat.
• Being very tired.
• Feeling dizzy, or feeling like you may pass out (faint).
• Having no desire to eat.
• Feeling like you may vomit (nauseous).
• Peeing (urinating) more at night.
• Feeling confused.
How is this treated?
This condition may be treated with:
• Medicines. These can be given to treat blood pressure and to make the heart muscles stronger.
• Changes in your daily life. These may include eating a healthy diet, staying at a healthy body weight, quitting tobacco and illegal drug use, or doing exercises.
• Surgery. Surgery can be done to open blocked valves, or to put devices in the heart, such as pacemakers.
• A donor heart (heart transplant). You will receive a healthy heart from a donor.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Treat other conditions as told by your doctor. These may include high blood pressure, diabetes, thyroid disease, or abnormal heart rhythms.
• Learn as much as you can about heart failure.
• Get support as you need it.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.
Summary
• Heart failure means that your heart is not able to pump blood in the right way.
• This condition is caused by high blood pressure, heart attack, or damage of the heart muscle.
• Symptoms of this condition include shortness of breath and swelling of the feet, ankles, legs, or belly. You may also feel very tired or feel like you may vomit.
• You may be treated with medicines, surgery, or changes in your daily life.
• Treat other health conditions as told by your doctor.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-11-06 Document Reviewed: 2020-11-06
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Cellulitis, Adult
Cellulitis is a skin infection. The infected area is often warm, red, swollen, and sore. It occurs most often in the arms and lower legs. It is very important to get treated for this condition.
What are the causes?
This condition is caused by bacteria. The bacteria enter through a break in the skin, such as a cut, burn, insect bite, open sore, or crack.
What increases the risk?
This condition is more likely to occur in people who:
• Have a weak body defense Swanson (immune Swanson).
• Have open cuts, burns, bites, or scrapes on the skin.
• Are older than 60 years of age.
• Have a blood sugar problem (diabetes).
• Have a long-lasting (chronic) liver disease (cirrhosis) or kidney disease.
• Are very overweight (obese).
• Have a skin problem, such as:
◦ Itchy rash (eczema).
◦ Slow movement of blood in the veins (venous stasis).
◦ Fluid buildup below the skin (edema).
• Have been treated with high-energy rays (radiation).
• Use IV drugs.
What are the signs or symptoms?
Symptoms of this condition include:
• Skin that is:
◦ Red.
◦ Streaking.
◦ Spotting.
◦ Swollen.
◦ Sore or painful when you touch it.
◦ Warm.
• A fever.
• Chills.
• Blisters.
How is this diagnosed?
This condition is diagnosed based on:
• Medical history.
• Physical exam.
• Blood tests.
• Imaging tests.
How is this treated?
Treatment for this condition may include:
• Medicines to treat infections or allergies.
• Home care, such as:
◦ Rest.
◦ Placing cold or warm cloths (compresses) on the skin.
• Hospital care, if the condition is very bad.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your doctor.
• If you were prescribed an antibiotic medicine, take it as told by your doctor. Do not stop taking it even if you start to feel better.
General instructions
• Drink enough fluid to keep your pee (urine) pale yellow.
• Do not touch or rub the infected area.
• Raise (elevate) the infected area above the level of your heart while you are sitting or lying down.
• Place cold or warm cloths on the area as told by your doctor.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.
Contact a doctor if:
• You have a fever.
• You do not start to get better after 1–2 days of treatment.
• Your bone or joint under the infected area starts to hurt after the skin has healed.
• Your infection comes back. This can happen in the same area or another area.
• You have a swollen bump in the area.
• You have new symptoms.
• You feel ill and have muscle aches and pains.
Get help right away if:
• Your symptoms get worse.
• You feel very sleepy.
• You throw up (vomit) or have watery poop (diarrhea) for a long time.
• You see red streaks coming from the area.
• Your red area gets larger.
• Your red area turns dark in color.
These symptoms may represent a serious problem that is an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• Cellulitis is a skin infection. The area is often warm, red, swollen, and sore.
• This condition is treated with medicines, rest, and cold and warm cloths.
• Take all medicines only as told by your doctor.
• Tell your doctor if symptoms do not start to get better after 1–2 days of treatment.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
